dialogues.text: That sounds great. But... John’s voice trails off. An awkward silence. The Valet arrives with Gwen's car. Sh looks at him expectantly:

dialogues.text: Look, I’ve got an early morning, so...

dialogues.speaker: GWEN
dialogues.text: Okay. Anyway, I really liked talking to you. Call me, okay? John nods absently. Gwen looks at him, his thoughts are m away. She gets into her car and drives off. Ed and Peter come outside and find John alone, staring intently down the street:

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: Where'd she go? John mutters.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I don’t know. INT. JOHN’S APARTMENT - BEDROOM CLOSET - NIGHT 44 A moth eats through a sweater in the dark. The closet doo swings open. John’s hand reaches in, pulls a chain. A nak bulb burns white. John looks restless, irritated. He yank empty suitcase from the top shelf, sending clothes and bo cascading to the floor. As he gathers them up, he’s pulle short by the sight of Mary’s RED OVERNIGHT CASE. It sits the corner where he left it almost a year ago. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He bends to his knees, moves his hand to the lock, hesita afraid to unlock the past. Finally, he lifts the 1: And there, staring up at him is reminder of all that he has lost. His hand touches her sc lipstick, a brush still twined with her red hair... John closes the case, slides it back into the corner. He grabs his suitcase, throws it on the bed, jamming in clot

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John drives quickly through empty streets, crosses the fourteenth street bridge. INT. JOHN’S CAR - CONTINUOUS “45 John is driving through the outskirts of Northern Virgini

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: {into cell phone) Hey, Ed. You were right. Gwen was very nice. If you talk to her, tell her, uh... I don’t know. Anyway, it’s about one o'clock. I’m kind of wired, so I’m heading down to Richmond tonight, talk to you later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John is speeding down the interstate. Traffic is thin. He passes under THE LIGHTED SIGN FOR RICHMOND. His car drives on into the night. INT. JOHN’S CAR - LATER 48 John squints, trying to stay focused on the road as he dr down a crest into a FOG BANK. He flexes his brakes. Suddenly... BLINK: Red lights flash across the dashboard. The car sta EXT. JOHN’S CAR - MOMENTS LATER 49 The car drifts out of the fog onto the shoulder and comes a stop.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. JOHN'S CAR
dialogues.text: John tries to restart the engine. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Come on, come on, come on... He looks around. A dark, empty road. It doesn’t feel righ He glances in his mirror. HIS POV: Nothing behind him. Not another pair of headligh Not even the interstate. John turns the key again. Silence. Not so much as the whi of the starter. He switches on the headlights. Nothing. H punches up the radio: dead. So is the car phone. John sma his palms on the wheel. He takes out his cell phone. It beeps, shuts down. Drained. He looks at his watch: 2:20 AM.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH THE WINDSHIELD
dialogues.text: Distant lightning flickers hypnotically. It seems to be moving from the ground up to the sky. JOHN, mystified, gets out of his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It‘s a cold night, and he tucks his hands under his arms. should put on his coat. THE LIGHTNING flickers violently, a few miles away. But w is the thunder? It’s silent, eerily silent, so quiet John hear his heart beating. Abruptly the lightning is extinguished. No stars. No moon light at all. JOHN feels a surge of anxiety. He’s alone at night in the middle of nowhere.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (low whisper) ..-Okay. Okay. John shrugs on his overcoat and locks the car. He looks u and down the road. Nothing. He walks in darkness. Now he hears a strange low rumble. What the hell is that? sound vibrates the road below his feet. Finally, he catches sight of a porch light on a distant farmhouse. Turning up his collar and plunging his hands i his pockets, John heads toward it at a fast clip.  52 53 23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John bownrds onto the porch. The house is dark, except fo single : 1b. No use putting it off: He knocks on the door Waits. Waits. A MAN opens the door. John smiles:

dialogues.speaker: _ JOHN
dialogues.text: Hi. My car broke down just up the road. May I use your phone? The Man stares at him, transfixed.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: t's him. This response makes no sense to John. A WOMAN steps into from the shadows behind the door; she peers nervously at as the Man raises a gun:

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I've been waiting for you, you son of a bitch. The Man grabs John by his lapels and hauls him inside. Th door shuts hard. INT. GORDON SMALLWOOD’S HOUSE - BATHROOM - NIGHT 53 The Man, GORDON SMALLWOOD, (43), holds his gun on... JOHN, who stands dressed in his overcoat in the Smallwood mildewy, pink shower stall. Gordon is sitting on the tank the toilet, his feet on the closed lid. He keeps the gun steady with his elbows on his knees.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Look, I don’t -

dialogues.speaker: GORDON
dialogues.text: Shut up. John shuts up. The two men watch each other, hearing the tread of approaching footsteps. The Woman - Gordon’s wife DENISE SMALLWOOD, (28) enters.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Honey, Connie’s here. John straightens slightly as (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A WOMAN enters, wearing a sheriff's deputy uniform under unzipped parka. She is SGT. CONNIE PARKER, (32) - blond, with keen blue e and an honest face. She calmly assesses the scene: John is enormously relieved.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Okay Gordy, why don’t you put away the gun and tell me what’s going on. Gordon keeps the gun trained on John. Connie places her h on the barrel and points it to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: GORDON
dialogues.text: This is the third night in a row he's come around, this sonofabitch is stalking - us -

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: - Look, my car broke down up the road, my name is John Klein and I -

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: - Let’s let Gordy finish, Mr. Klein. Gordon speaks with a disturbing edge of fear in his voice

dialogues.speaker: GORDON
dialogues.text: Two nights ago, at 2:30, there’s this bang on the door. I get up, and here's this guy, says he wants to use the phone. But there’s something creepy about him, right? So I tell him to get lost. No big deal. But last night, at 2:30 on the dot, guess who’s back?

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: You’re sure it was Mr. Klein here? Gordon stares straight into John’s eyes:

dialogues.speaker: GORDON
dialogues.text: Absolutely positive.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (under his breath) This is crazy. Gordon has good ears. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GORDON
dialogues.text: (sternly) I am not crazy.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I didn’t say - Connie holds up a hand:

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: (to Gordon) So then what?

dialogues.speaker: GORDON
dialogues.text: So last night I warned him off my property. I used the word “trespass,” Connie. And he still came back. (to John) I had the right to shoot you on my porch. You’re lucky I’m a Christian.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: He'd have actually had to be inside the house, Gordon.

dialogues.speaker: GORDON
dialogues.text: Fine. So tonight I figured maybe the dumb fuck -~-

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: (sternly) Gordon.

dialogues.speaker: GORDON
dialogues.text: -- might come back again, and sure enough, here he is! John turns to Sgt. Parker, taking pains to demonstrate th he is the sanest person in the room.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Officer, there must be some mistake. I’ve never been here before in my life, I’ve never seen these people, I live in D.C. Check my wallet. Connie calmly reaches into John’s pocket. She pulls out h wallet, flips it open, spots his press pass. Her eyes jum his face.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: The Washington Post. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Do I have to keep standing in the shower? INT/EXT. GORDON’S FRONT DOOR - LATER 54 John follows Connie to the door, not sure whether to be relieved or worried.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: You can wait for me outside, Mr. Klein. John heads through the door without a word. Nothing makes sense to him.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Gordon) We’ll run a check on him. Anyone else comes by, forget the gun, okay? Just call me.

dialogues.speaker: GORDON
dialogues.text: Find out what he wants. Connie squeezes Gordon’s shoulder. He goes to the doorway watches JOHN standing beside Parker’s Patrol car. Connie turns to Denise. She pantomimes tipping a bottle t her lips: has Gordon been drinking? Denise shakes her head no.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: So you didn’t actually see the guy yourself, did you? Before tonight?

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: No. But I heard the knocks, three nights in a row. EXT. GORDON’S HOUSE - CONTINUOUS 55 John sees them all step onto the porch. Then, in spite of odd circumstances, he watches as Connie, Gordon and Denis a distinctly small-town thing: They all say a friendly go night to each other. Hug. Then, as Connie walks towards John, Gordon shouts:

dialogues.speaker: GORDON
dialogues.text: You don’t scare me!  56 57 58 27.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John sits next to Connie in the front seat. Connie pulls onto the empty road.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: I’m giving you a ride to town. Unless you want to sleep in your car. I can call a tow for the morning. They pull up behind John‘s car.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: You probably want to get your bag?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: You probably brought a bag.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Oh - He steps out of the cruiser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John crosses the road, opens his trunk, takes out his weekender. He sees Connie on the two-way. He passes throu her headlights, climbs back in the Prowler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's inside the car in time to HEAR the DISPATCHER over t two-way. DISPATCHER’S VOICE -- man’s clean as Clorox, if you believe the computer.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Copy. Thanks, Avis. She clicks off, gives John a little shrug, shifts into dr Connie puts it as plainly as she can:

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You’re a long way from D.C. What are you doing here? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Driving through.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: We’re not on the way anyplace, Mr. Klein. John is silent - he can’t explain how he got here. He sta out the window. They’re passing through dark, quiet littl Point Pleasant. Population 6,000. CONNIE (cont’d) Relax. I recognize you. (smiles) “Meet the Press.”

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You saw that?

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: We're not all bumpkins. Connie steers into the parking lot of a chain motel.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: So I’m not under arrest?

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Well, you didn’t steal anything, you didn’t hurt anyone, there’s no breaking and entering...

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You had trouble with them before?

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Gordy and Denise? Naw. They're good people, but... She hesitates, she knows she shouldn’t say this: CONNIE (cont'd) Things have been a little strange around here lately. She leans across him to open the door, but mostly to smel his breath.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I guarantee I’m sober. He climbs out. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: You still haven't told me what you’re doing here. In the middle of the night. John hefts his bag.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: When I find out, I'll let you know. (beat) Where am I, anyway? Connie points to a sign: WELCOME TO POINT PLEASANT. She watches him walk into the motel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sleepy, cranky NIGHT MANAGER runs John’s charge. John concentrates on the road map stretched out under the glas the check-in counter. His finger traces Washington to Richmond, a straight shot interstate, not more than 120 miles. THE NIGHT MANAGER returns with John’s credit card.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You think you could show me where we are on the map?

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT MANAGER
dialogues.text: We’re right on the state line. John traces to the Virginia/West Virginia border. The nig manager snorts with disgust. Tourists. Spare him.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT MANAGER
dialogues.text: With Ohio. He stabs a spot 400 miles away from John’s finger. Point Pleasant is on the Ohio River. John's finger hesitantly tracks the tiny spidery lines fr Richmond to Point Pleasant. There’s not even a primary ro between them. The room key clinks down on the glass. JOHN keeps staring at the map. It’s not possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As John walks from the office to his room, we spot the Prowler parked across the street: Connie is making notes under the interior light.  61 62 63 64 30. INT. JOHN’S MOTEL ROOM - NIGHT 61 The room is dark. John jerks awake, disoriented. He was asleep in his clothes on top of the bedspread, which he h cocooned around himself. He doesn’t know where he is for moment. Then he HEARS it. Faint BREATHING, someone BREATH something BREATHING. He reaches for the bedside lamp and switches it on. The breathing stops. Silent now. Just a dull, empty, standard issue motel room. John swings his legs off the bed and le forward on his knees. Bad dreams. He stands up. His cell phone is recharging on the chair. He heads for the bathro for a glass of water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John turns on the tap, splashes water on his face, looks studies his reflection. ANGLE FROM BEHIND THE MIRROR. WE PULL BACK: John’s image framed by the mirror. The sound of the running tap fades his image recedes, then disappears.

dialogues.speaker: FADE TO BLACK
dialogues.text: EXT. OTTO’S CAR REPAIR - POINT PLEASANT - AFTERNOON 63 John is on his cell phone. In the background, OTTO’S head buried under the hood of John’s car.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: {into phone) ..Look - even if I was doing eighty the whole way it would have taken six hours to get here...

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: What time did you leave D.C?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: One o'clock. Besides, my gas tank doesn’t even get four hundred miles. It’s one thing to zone out while you're driving, but to stop for gas too?

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: John, I’m sure there's a logical explanation for all this. Don’t worry about your pal the Governor, I'll cover you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: John sees Otto slam the hood on his car.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Thanks, Ed. Uh, listen, I got to go.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: She's running fine, Mr. Klein, I can't find a damn thing wrong with her.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: How much do I owe you?

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: Nothing. I said I couldn't find anything wrong. This town just keeps getting weirder and weirder... John spots Gordon Smallwood and ANOTHER MAN loading produ onto a truck across the street. John tosses his weekender into the back seat and walks quickly towards Gordon. Gordon eyes John warily, arms folded across his chest.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (smoothly) Mr. Smallwood, will you accept my apology? I’m afraid I might have been a little rude last night. Gordon nods stoically. JOHN (cont'd) Listen, you're sure it was me who came by those last two nights, huh?

dialogues.speaker: GORDON
dialogues.text: Look, mister, Connie called me this morning, says you check out, and that’s good enough for me. I'm perfectly willing to let it go. But I don’t drink anymore and I don’t lie and as far as I know, I’m not crazy, so if you’re accusing me - John pulls Gordon aside.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: -- No, no, not at all. (confidentially) Here's the thing: I don’t know how I ended up here last night. I didn’t even (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JOHN (cont'd) know I was in West Virginia. Somehow, between one and two-thirty last night I travelled four hundred miles, ended up on that road, and I have no memory of it whatsoever.

dialogues.speaker: GORDON
dialogues.text: You shittin’ me?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: No, I wish I was. Long awkward silence. John shakes Gordon’s hand goodbye a walks back to his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John pulls onto the road. As he circles past Gordon, thei EYES LOCK for a moment. EXT. JOHN‘’S CAR - HIGHWAY - DUSK 66 John leaves town the way he came in. He passes a sign reading: “Point Pleasant City Limits” EXT. GORDON SMALLWOOD’S HOUSE - NIGHT 67 The distant farmhouse is dark except for a single bulb lighting the porch. No one is visible inside.

dialogues.speaker: A MAN'S ARM RISES INTO THE FRAME
dialogues.text: His watch reads 2:15 a.m. WE PULL BACK AND SEE: John’s face reflected in his car’s view mirror. He’s staking out Gordon’s farmhouse from the woods across the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The high grass bends as SOMETHING moves menacingly toward the back of John’s car.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. JOHN'S CAR
dialogues.text: John cocks his ear. A rustling sound. Something is coming towards him, slowly, steadily. He scans around, it’s dark too dark to see. An SUV rolls quietly up beside him, headlights off.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: I was afraid I’d see you here. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ve Ont +g - FT tg oa * erm “Une cone Now — ay

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Just your odd reports, folks seeing things they can’t explain. So they all come to me.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I've had a few odd moments of my own since last night. If there’s other people in town feeling as confused as I am right now, I'd sure like to know. There’s something in his voice or his face or maybe both.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Okay. In the last few months people have come up to me and reported seeing strange things... And I'm not talking about the town speed-freak, I‘m talking about honest, hard-working, church-going folks. I’ve known these people their whole lives, and they seem downright embarrassed to be bringing it up.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Bringing what up?

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: It’s hard to explain.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Try me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rows of florescent lights pop on, one after another. Conn locks the glass front doors behind her and John.

dialogues.speaker: A STACK OF REPORTS, (LATER)
dialogues.text: spread across a desk. Photos, eyewitness reports, maps, p records...

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Weird lights, strange phone calls, ghosts, you. You name it. John flips through the reports. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CONNIE (cont’d) Seeing a UFO is one thing. It’s almost a status symbol nowadays. But what do you do when someone walks in and tells you this showed up in their backyard? She tosses a sketch across the desk. John picks it up. And almost passes out. It’s a drawing, of a man, with hug

dialogues.speaker: JOHN'S MEMORY
dialogues.text: A yellow pad with Mary’s identical sketch.

dialogues.speaker: ACCIDENT SITE IN D.C. 74
dialogues.text: THE LOW HANGING BRANCH with red lights for EYES flies rap towards us. Mary's drawing and the branch superimpose, and for a spli second, John sees it: Mothman.

dialogues.speaker: BACK AT THE POLICE STATION
dialogues.text: John’s face is white.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Who saw this?

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: A couple of people.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I want to meet them. I need to talk to them. Can you help me? Connie looks into his eyes: He's dead serious. EXT. LUCY GRIFFIN'’S HOUSE - DAY 76 John waits in the patrol car while... ON THE PORCH: Connie talks to LUCY GRIFFIN, (53), a tough chubby woman with bright red cheeks. After a moment, Conn looks back at John and nods.  77 78 36. INT. LUCY GRIFFIN’S KITCHEN - LATER 77 John and Connie drink coffee at the kitchen table with Lu and her son NAT GRIFFIN, (24), a slacker living at home w his mom.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: It’s been going on about a month, every Wednesday night at the poison plant. John looks a question at Connie: “Poison plant?”

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: The hills around the Alanco chemical factory. It’s a make-out spot.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: (smiles) Used to be. Now we just watch the lights.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What lights?

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: I don’t know, man, just these weird lights zipping around in the sky.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What do you think they are? How would you describe them?

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: Nobody knows, dude, the sky's just totally freaking out.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Only Wednesdays?

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: That's when they seem to show up. Lucy refills their coffee cups. Connie takes out the bird sketch:

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Lucy, would you mind telling Mr. Klein about the time you saw this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all stand near a blue pine tree that towers over the yard and house: (CONTINUED)

78 Lucy It was right here. There was only a foot or so between its head 4 that branch so t’ st makes it, what, e. -t feet tall? I was doing dishes and I just happened to look out the kitchen window. EXT. BACKYARD - NIGHT - FLASHBACK - MOTHMAN’S POV 79 We descend into the back yard, landing under the blue pin tree. We watch Lucy through the kitchen window. She stare back at.us, mesmerized.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: At first, all I could see were these two red eyes. I kept on looking at it, I couldn't stop. I’ve never had that feeling before, like I couldn’t move. The only way I can explain is that the whole thing just wasn’t right. I know that may not make sense, but that’s the only way I can put it into words.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE, (PRESENT TIME - LUCY'S BACKYARD)
dialogues.text: CAMERA rises, peering down at Lucy, John, Connie and Nat: Lucy (cont‘d) Then, I guess it saw me too, ‘cause all of a sudden these giant wings just flared out and it took off.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (to Nat) Did you see it too?... Nat shakes his head no. John’s eyes fix on something. He walks over to the tree, reaches out his hand, touches it. He runs his fingers alo the tree bark - a large section is scorched black.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mrs. Griffin, I don’t mean to pry, but...Have you had any headaches or blackouts or anything like that recently?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: (smiles) You think maybe I have a brain tumor? John’s jaw almost hits the ground. Connie explains: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Lucy’s a radiologist out at St. Joseph’s Hospital.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: No symptoms yet, Mr. Klein. But it was sweet of you to ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FIRE CHIEF JOSH JESSUP, (55), a stout bulldog of a man si with John and Connie in the fire station while, in the background, his men scrub the fire truck.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I guess they started about two months ago, the strange phone calls. All hours. The first one was just a loud beeping - noise. Now it’s mostly creaking, howling sounds - and once, it was a man talking really fast in some foreign language. Maybe Swedish or something like that.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Have you had the line checked?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (nods) I even had our number changed. But before I got a chance to give it out to anyone the calls started again. John glances at Connie: is she buying this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John sits beside Connie, reading through her reports.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: So - do you think Lucy and Josh really experienced anything?

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Like I said, they’re honest people. John stares out the window: low blue hills roll out in al directions, lit by brilliant winter light.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: How long have you lived here? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: My whole life. Grew up just over those hills.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: A farm?

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Shucks no. A real live house. Indoor plumbing and everything.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: We even had shoes for church and schoolin’ and such.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (laughs) Alright, alright. Connie glances over: this is the first time he’s smiled s they met. He looks five years younger - a whole different person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Prowler’s headlights illuminate a rusted chain with a sign: “ROAD CLOSED - NO TRESPASSING” Connie climbs out, pulls the chain aside, drives through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Connie points a flashlight as John and two teenagers, C.J.(17) and HOLLY(14), walk up the crest of a small hill One of C.J.'s eyes is slightly puffy with a blotch of red C.J. We were parked up here and sort of making out in the back seat...

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: It’s a starlit, moonless night. C.J. and Holly are naked head to toe, humping wildly in the back seat of his white Chevy Impala. From beneath their heavy panting, a low electronic hum rumbles. Flesh gropes. The rumble slowly rises. Suddenly,

dialogues.speaker: A SEARING RED LIGHT
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED

dialogues.text: Gordon?

dialogues.speaker: GORDON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (talking fast) Look, I know I sounded a little bit crazy today, but things have been getting weird out here.

dialogues.speaker: . JOHN
dialogues.text: Gordon, slow down --

dialogues.speaker: GORDON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: -- He’s here.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Who is?

dialogues.speaker: GORDON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Cold. He’s here. Right now. He’s standing right next to me. John turns away from Connie and sits on the edge of the b The mood in the room has completely shifted:

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Let me talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: GORDON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Sure. Hang on. Then he turns to Connie and covers the mouthpiece:

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Get over to Gordon's quick, he says Indrid Cold is there. Connie doesn’t ask questions, she just grabs her things a heads for the door. A thin, monotone VOICE -- supposedly that of Indrid Cold comes on the line:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hello John Klein. John tries to collect his thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Who is this?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: My name is Indrid Cold. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: John quickly attaches his tape recorder -- an expensive digital device -- to his phone.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Unless, of course, you're Gordon Smallwood.

dialogues.speaker: INDRID COLD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Your father was born in Racine, Wisconsin. You lived in a green house on Monroe street. You can’t remember how your mother looked. John realizes he’s sweating, his breathing has quickened. makes himself breathe normally.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Okay, you’ve got my attention. What color shirt am I wearing?

dialogues.speaker: INDRID COLD, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Red shirt, three buttons. Correct. Hmm. John looks around the room. The curtains ar open. He pulls them shut. He looks down and sees his watc his shoe.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Where’s my watch?

dialogues.speaker: INDRID COLD, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Shoe under bed. He looks around the room: Hidden cameras? An elaborate tr He shuts off all the lights. Then plunges his hand into h overnight bag.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What am I holding in my hand?

dialogues.speaker: INDRID COLD, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Cream stick. John pulls his hand from his bag: he holds a small tube o Chapstick. Suddenly, an explanation occurs.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (smiling) Indrid Cold -- are you reading my mind?

dialogues.speaker: INDRID COLD, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: I have no need to. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Okay...John grabs a paperback from the stack near his bed but doesn’t open it. The real test:

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What's the third line on page...fifty- one?

dialogues.speaker: INDRID COLD, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: (instantly) ‘“-- Face unadorned held a naked promise that her figure did --” John flips on the lamp, opens the book, finds the page, s the line, takes a sharp breath. Correct.

dialogues.speaker: INDRID COLD, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: (cont ‘d) Still more proof John Klein?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Connie’s speeding Prowler hugs the curves of a winding ba road, blue and red gumballs flashing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John is still on the phone with Indrid Cold. His mood has shifted from skepticism to anxious fascination:

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What do you look like?

dialogues.speaker: INDRID COLD, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Variable.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I want to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: INDRID COLD, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: We already have. You frighten easily. You‘re afraid right now.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You seem to know a lot. Can you tell me something...What happened to my wife? A long silence. The silence makes John nervous.

dialogues.speaker: INDRID COLD, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Why ask me what you already know? John takes a breath and closes his eyes: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Where is Mary Klein right now? John grips the phone, his hand slick with sweat, waiting.

dialogues.speaker: INDRID COLD, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: The one who was Mary Klein cannot be found by looking. (beat) Contact is possible. See you in time. The line ERUPTS IN A HIGH PITCHED WHINE, a metallic WHIST piercing John’s ear. He flings the phone away. The receiv keeps SCREECHING on the floor. John stares at the phone. SCREECH becomes a terrible CREAK, replaced by STATIC, the nothing, finally a dial tone. John forces himself to retr the receiver and place it back on the cradle. Sweat beads roll down into his eyes. EXT. GORDON SMALLWOOD’S HOUSE - NIGHT 122 Connie’s hand pounds on the door. Nothing. She pounds aga Nothing. Finally, a light goes on inside and... GORDON SMALLWOOD opens the door slowly. He’s in boxer sho hair-mussed, fresh from bed. He squints out at Connie:

dialogues.speaker: GORDON
dialogues.text: What's up, Connie? Everything okay?

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: (urgently) -- Did you just call John?

dialogues.speaker: GORDON
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) I've been asleep since nine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establish a high-tech looking facility - clearly the non- nonsense domain of science.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John sits in the SOUND LAB surrounded by some of the most sophisticated sound analysis equipment in America. He lis to a tape of last night’s phone call along with: SONNY BERGER, (45) a sound engineer -- good-natured, bear and at least 300 pounds. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As Indrid Cold’s VOICE comes on, Sonny points to the Voic Frequency Gauge:

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: See? It’s sticking up here around 1950 cycles per second. The lowest it gets is maybe, 1930 or so... Then John's VOICE comes on the tape. SONNY (cont'd) Yours is way down here in normal vocal range: anywhere from 1000 to 1200 cycles per second.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: So this guy’s vocal range is higher than mine?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: (laughs) ) You‘re bullshitting me, right? How’d you do it?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Do what?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Create the voice. It’s a good mimic, but comes on, 1900 cycles per second? Groundhogs don’t go that high.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: So what the hell is it? As the tape plays, Sonny isolates Indrid Cold’s voice and does a computer search for matches...Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: As near as I can figure, it’s some sort of electrical impulse. But whatever it is, it isn’t coming out of human vocal cords. INT. JOHN KLEIN’S CAR - DUSK 125 John drives back from Charleston, cell phone to his ear, leaving a message:

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (frayed) Cyrus, it’s John, it’s Wednesday night, (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 125 126 In it

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JOHN (cont'd) I’m still stuck down here in West Virginia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John's car passes through a tollbooth, exiting the main highway. There’s something eerie about it, but John is wrapped up in his call and doesn't notice.

dialogues.speaker: . JOHN
dialogues.text: (continuous) I’m going to need a few more days to wrap - things up...I/11 call you in a couple of days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cold wind howls outside. John lies in bed, tossing and turning in the dark...

dialogues.speaker: LATER 128
dialogues.text: Now the lights are on. He sits on the edge of the bed, CHANNEL SURFING. He clicks off the TV and throws down the remote...

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER 129
dialogues.text: Now he's dressed. He grabs his keys and he’s out the door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John stands on the Porch talking to Denise. She shakes he head, points towards town. INT/EXT. JOHN’S CAR - PARKING AREA/HILLTOP CLEARING - NIG John's car rolls to a stop at the hilltop near the Alanco Chemical Plant. No other cars parked, no sign of Gordon.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, COFFEE SHOP
dialogues.text: John drives past - it’s closed for the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John drives by -- also closed. He drives on.  134

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John spots Gordon mid-span, leaning over the railing, down at the rushing water. He’s not wearing a coat. John jumps out:

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Gordon! Gordon doesn’t seem to hear him. JOHN (cont'd) Gordon! 66. 134 staring John reaches Gordon’s side, places his hand on his should Gordon stares out at nothing in particular.

dialogues.speaker: GORDON
dialogues.text: (calmly) I used to walk up here when I was a little kid. We’re right between West Virginia and Ohio. So technically, I figure we're not in either one...

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Come on Gordon it’s freezing out here, you want to warm up in my car? Gordon slowly shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: GORDON
dialogues.text: Can’t. I’m waiting for him. John nods, waits for him to continue: GORDON (CONT’D) John, everybody in this town is looking at me like I’m insane...You know why? John goes to answer, but Gordon continues: GORDON (CONT‘D) It’s because I’m telling the truth...Denise, all the others, they don’t know, John. I do.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What do you know, Gordon?

dialogues.speaker: GORDON
dialogues.text: I been lying awake at night -- feel like I’m sleeping, but I’m awake. That’s when (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: GORDON (cont'd) I hear him...When I hear his voice lately, I swear to God -- I feel better. John stares at Gordon, incredulous: Gordon looks as sure himself and resolute as when they first met. John takes a moment to gather his thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I have an idea, but before I tell you what it is, I want you to know I don’t think you‘re crazy. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: GORDON
dialogues.text: (calmly) I’m not crazy.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I’ve heard about a program at the University. They work with people who’ve had strange experiences, and try to figure out if these events are occurring...outwardly or inwardly. You see what I mean?

dialogues.speaker: GORDON
dialogues.text: You think I’m imagining all this?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I don’t know, Gordon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John drives past the scrap yard next to the UNFINISHED HIGHWAY where Gordon claims to have met Indrid Cold. As J drives under the elevated RAMP TO NOWHERE...

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: ..-his face suddenly contorts with fear. He looks around terrified: what’s happening to him? Sweat beads on his forehead, he tries to move his arms, h hands, his legs -- he’s paralyzed with fear. The car continues to roll forward, increasing speed. Ten Feet...Twenty...Thirty! His fear escalates into panic. Ev yard an eternity of unbearable terror. At fifty feet, he crosses an_ invisible border: his fear leaves as suddenly it came. John stops the car. He catches his breath, gathering his nerve to investigate further.  137 138 139 68.

dialogues.text: ohn climbs ovt of his car, plants his feet on the aspha?t looks around. Nothing out of the ordinary. No sign of Indrid Cold or an other explanation -- what did he just pass through? He walks back towards the area, slowly, cautiously, tryin stay calm. Then he takes one step too many. He’s back inside the zone. The air becomes perfectly stil ALL AUDIBLE SOUNDS -- animals, birds, even insects -- are sucked into silence. The night becomes darker, too dark. John's breathing becomes shallow and fast. He falls to th ground, engulfed in fear.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I couldn't move. I don’t know what it was, I was more afraid than I’ve ever been in my whole life. I was just a few feet from where I came in, but it felt like I'd never make it back... INT. CONNIE’S PROWL CAR - DAY 138 Connie listens intently to John as she drives towards the unfinished highway.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: ...I’m on my knees, and I’m hyperventilating. I couldn’t stand up. It took me a half hour to crawl the five feet out of there. John looks at Connie. She doesn’t know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is it, up ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Connie slows the Prowler to a crawl, then brakes. They ge out.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: It began here?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Right over here, I think. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: John and Connie walk slowly. John tries to get his bearin JOHN (cont ’d) I remember the ramp was here...so this must be it. He starts to walk. Connie joins him and they step over an imaginary line together. They look at each other. She sha her head. Nothing. JOHN (cont'd) Let‘s keep going. They walk further. Nothing. John stops, perplexed, shakes head. JOHN (cont'd) (quietly) I swear, it was right here. Connie looks at him. She doesn’t feel it. But last night, John did. Connie looks into his eyes, sees a man shaken f an experience he can't explain. She takes his hand in her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk back and forth, back and forth, back and forth. Birds chirp, the winter sun is shining brightly, and we p back on two people searching for an imaginary circle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We INTERCUT between John and Gordon -- as each is intervi by DR. LEE OKSTER, (37), friendly, and way too good looki to be in a lab coat:

dialogues.speaker: OKSTER
dialogues.text: As a child, were you prone to seizures?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: OKSTER
dialogues.text: Were you often left at home alone?

dialogues.speaker: GORDON
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: OKSTER
dialogues.text: Did you have a guardian angel or secret friend? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: OKSTER
dialogues.text: Do you sometimes have trouble discerning dreams from actual memories?... Gordon stares into the middle distance; he slowly nods. . OKSTER (cont'd) Mr. Smallwood? Gordon looks up, as if waking from a dream, as we go...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT again between John and Gordon with small electri patches taped to their faces and skulls. EEG printouts sc out beside them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Okster shows John and Gordon their EEG printouts.

dialogues.speaker: OKSTER
dialogues.text: Alright, this line here? It measures activity in the temporal lobe, the visual and perceptual center of the brain. Disorders in this area have been linked to both alien encounters and near-death experiences.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Disorders like a brain tumor?

dialogues.speaker: OKSTER
dialogues.text: Maybe. But neither you nor Mr. Smallwood seem to have any temporal lobe abnormalities.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: So what does that leave?

dialogues.speaker: OKSTER
dialogues.text: You might have been exposed to an electromagnetic field. Certain people are more sensitive than others to these EM waves, and it stimulates their temporal lobes causing vivid hallucinations. Gordon squints skeptically:

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: OKSTER (cont’d) Bright lights, voices, feelings of terror, distortions of time and even sightings of humanoid creatures. Gordon looks freaked, John doesn’t know what to think. INT. JOHN KLEIN’ MOTEL ROOM - NIGHT 143

dialogues.speaker: A BOOK PAGE
dialogues.text: WITH INSECT EYES AND WINGS. It looks like something from Ars Moriendi -- “The Art of Dying” -- Medieval Christian texts on death.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: “The Nocturnal Butterfly. Also called Mothman. In ancient cultures, the moth represents a form of the psyche, or the soul immortally trapped in the hellish death realms...” Connie sits on the edge of a bed, wearing her uniform. Sh reads from a MYTHOLOGY BOOK. John’s weekender lies open on the other bed: he’s packing It‘s late. A cold wind howls outside. CONNIE (CONT’D) (reading) --.“Mothman is one of the most obscure and frightening mythological creatures of the underworld...” Connie closes the book. She’s read enough for tonight. Sh tosses it on the floor. John stops packing and looks at h CONNIE (CONT’D) (softly) What time’s your flight?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Eight AM. Connie looks away, missing him already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON WEST 83RD STREET: John stands in a doorway across from brownstone Criterion Apartments. He sees... A MAN emerges from the apartment building: stocky, red fa and crew-cut hair. Looks like a retired drill sergeant. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: John glances at the author photo on the book he holds, “Things Unseen”. Sure enough, it’s the same guy: ALBERT L John dodges across the street and stops him.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Mr. Leek... Leek stops in his tracks, alarmed. John holds up one of t Bird-Man sketches: JOHN (cont'd) - Do you know what this is? Leek’s eyes flick from the sketch to John’s face:

dialogues.speaker: LEEK
dialogues.text: Who the hell are you?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: John Klein. I called you. I need to know about this. Leek stares at him, considers -- then pushes quickly past

dialogues.speaker: LEEK
dialogues.text: I’m sorry but I’m already late. John follows after him down the crowded street.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Have you ever seen this thing? Leek keeps walking, trying to ignore the man following hi JOHN (cont'd) (shouting over street noise) I need your help, Mr. Leek? Leek finally stops and turns -- John almost runs into him

dialogues.speaker: LEEK
dialogues.text: Where are they seeing him?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: {out of breath) Point Pleasant, West Virginia... He stares at John, making up his mind: should he bother? Leek grabs the sketch from John and gazes at it. He looks like he’s staring at his own obituary. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LEEK
dialogues.text: (quiet, to himself) Mothman. John’s eyes go wide.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (a statement) You can help me, can’t you? Leek nods.

dialogues.speaker: LEEK
dialogues.text: Follow me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John follows Leek into the giant, dusty old bookstore. Shelves tower overhead; stacks of books line the floor; aisles roll out in all directions, disappearing into murk darkness. ANGLE ON AISLE: John watches Leek scan the titles, his he tilted to the side. He plucks a book off the shelves:

dialogues.speaker: LEEK
dialogues.text: Ah, here we are... Leek flips through a book and stops on A PAINTING OF A GI MAN WITH WINGS. It looks like something out of Greek mythology. John shudders.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Mothman?

dialogues.speaker: LEEK
dialogues.text: That’s what the Ukrainians called him. Rough translation, of course. There were a hundred sightings in Chernobyl the year the nuclear plant went down.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Jesus. Leek turns to A GRAINY PHOTOGRAPH, the kind we’ve all see blurry, poorly framed -- but instead of a UFO, a Moth-lik figure hovers in the sky.

dialogues.speaker: LEEK
dialogues.text: Galveston, 1969, just before the hurricane. They saw it. But seeing isn’t always believing. There’s never been a single shred of evidence that any of (MORE) (CONTINUED)
145 LEEK (cont'd) these things exist materially; not for more than a short time, anyway. No one’s ever seen any Bigfoot boé.es or crashed UFO's.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What about Roswell?

dialogues.speaker: LEEK
dialogues.text: Come on. You work in Washington. Is that braintrust capable of keeping that kind of secret? John rubs his eyes, confused:

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: So you're saying these things don’t exist?

dialogues.speaker: LEEK
dialogues.text: Sure they exist. There’s all kinds of things that exist all around us that we never see, right? Electricity, microwaves, infra-red waves. You know, they’ve been around forever, they show up in cave paintings. They’re a normal condition of the planet, they're just not part of our consensus of what constitutes physical reality.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (frustrated) But what are they?

dialogues.speaker: LEEK
dialogues.text: Look, you're asking for an explanation for something that can’t be explained rationally.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: But why do they show-up before all these disasters? Leek re-shelves the book, turns to John:

dialogues.speaker: LEEK
dialogues.text: You know all that build-up of energy before something happens? The way your hair stands up before lightning strikes? That's when they cross over --

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: -- What do you mean, before something happens? Do they cause disasters? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LEEK
dialogues.text: Why would they need to? No, my theory is they foreshadow death and disaster. John lets that sink in, then:

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What do they want?

dialogues.speaker: LEEK
dialogues.text: I have no idea. What you really want to know is why you.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Okay. Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: LEEK
dialogues.text: You think you're special. Trust me, you're not. You just got in their way.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Got in their way?

dialogues.speaker: LEEK
dialogues.text: You noticed them. And they noticed that you noticed them. Most people aren’t sensitive enough to see them without some sort of trauma. John winces. Leek studies him, leans in. LEEK (cont ‘d) Are you fixated on death, Mr. Klein? John is silent. Leek nods knowingly, then walks down the aisle and out the door. John follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loud, crowded, and cold. John and Leek walk into the wind

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Last week my friend got a strange phone call from a spirit or entity or whatever. It seemed to know... everything. Like God.

dialogues.speaker: LEEK
dialogues.text: (continuing for him) And *t made predictions, and they came true... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (nods, excited) Yeah. He called himself Indrid Cold. John searches Leek’s face for a sign of recognition; Leek just shrugs. The name means nothing to him.

dialogues.speaker: LEEK
dialogues.text: If your “friend” thinks he’s talking to God, he’s off by more than a few degrees.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: But how could he know all this stuff? Leek stops walking. He looks around, trying to figure out way to explain.

dialogues.speaker: LEEK
dialogues.text: Look up there... John looks where Leek is pointing... A SKYSCRAPER: Ten stories up, a window-washer squeegees t side of a glass building.

dialogues.speaker: LEEK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If there was a car crash on Eighty Fourth and Riverside that window washer up there could probably see it. Doesn’t mean he’s God -- or even any smarter than we are. But from where he’s sitting, he can see a little further down the road.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: But they’ve gotta be more advanced then us. Why don’t they just come right out and say what’s on their minds? Leek nods.

dialogues.speaker: LEEK
dialogues.text: You're more advanced than.a cockroach -- ever try explaining yourself to one? They continue down the street, each lost in their own thoughts. John breaks the silence:

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: So, what about Point Pleasant?

dialogues.speaker: LEEK
dialogues.text: How many people have seen it? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I don’t know, ten, maybe twenty? Leek stops dead in his tracks, looks John in the eyes.

dialogues.speaker: LEEK
dialogues.text: Don’t go back there, Mr. Klein.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: LEEK
dialogues.text: Listen to me, something terrible is going to happen in Point Pleasant. John is struck by the sudden fear that has clouded Leek’s face. LEEK (cont’d) Nothing you do can stop it. Don’t go back, stay away, and stay away from me...I can’t talk about this any more. Leek starts to walk away, but John’s desperation demands answer. He pulls Leek violently by the arm.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Look, Mr. Leek, there’s got to be a reason I ended up in Point Pleasant... something brought me there. Leek pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: LEEK
dialogues.text: If it brought you there, it brought you there to die. LEEK disappears down a dark staircase to the subway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John has put off his flight and spends hours walking circ around Times Square, wrestling with unanswered questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON WEST 83RD STREET: John waits outside the entrance to Leek’s brownstone. When someone leaves, he rushes to the before it locks, slips in the building.  149
INT. LEEK’S APT BUILDING - HALLWAY - MORNING 149 John knocks. Leek cracks the doc open, displeased.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Please, I need to talk to you. Leek stares coldly. JCAN (cont’d) I need to know what happened to you. Leek’s face darkens, clouded by a bad memory. He lets the door swing open. INT. LEEK’S APARTMENT - MORNING 149A John follows him down a long hallway into the KITCHEN. John nods.

dialogues.speaker: LEEK
dialogues.text: You didn’t sleep last night did you?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: LEEK
dialogues.text: Once they get to you, it’s hard to sleep, isn’t it? LEEK (cont’d) You cross a line between what’s real and what’s not real... Leek pours himself a cup of tea and sits down at a table across from John. LEEK (cont’d) I was a physics professor at Cornell, tenured, you can look me up. One day I started hearing voices. The voices became messages. Before long, I was fully convinced that I was receiving predictions of disaster from “outside intelligences.”

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: But you were, weren’t you?

dialogues.speaker: LEEK
dialogues.text: John, I_had tapes of their voices! But so what? Nobody cared. I knew a building was (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: 149A CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LEEK (cont'd) going to blow up, I tried to prevent it, but no one listened...

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
